content:
I was watching this thread because I think I know what could be going on, but needed confirmation that the messages are indeed being sent and not just being saved in a Sent folder… :)

Something that could be causing this is Thunderbird somehow saving your drafts in Outbox, which is a special folder in Local Folders it uses to keep messages waiting to be sent. Now, I don't think you're really saving your drafts there and the possible explanation may end up being a little funnier, but just to be sure, what are your account Copies & Folders settings for Drafts? Where are your drafts supposed to be stored according to those settings?

If they're being saved in the right Drafts folder, what could be going on here is that somehow (presumably a bug) has caused that folder to be flagged as if it was an Outbox folder, thus causing the strange behaviour you're observing…

Install the following add-on in order to be able to see and change folder flags:

https://addons.thunderbird.net/thunderbird/addon/folderflags/

After installing it, in Thunderbird right-click on the folder that's being used to store your drafts, choose Properties and select the Flags tab. Does it show the Outbox flag ticked there? If so, uncheck it, click OK, and that should fix the problem.

This is IMAP or POP?

The main problem at the root of not receiving emails is Third Party Anti-Virus software. I'd suggest that, if you have any installed (especially Norton or Bitdefender), you switch off Email protection temporarily and see if it's magically resolved.

You could start Windows in Safe Mode with Networking but that would be pretty much the same reason for switching off Email Protection.

content:
Does the user name/email address in the 'From' section of your email (1) match the User name in your SMTP Settings (2) and the email address in your Server Settings (3)?

1 - Hamburger (top right)/Account Settings - click on the name of the account through which you are sending the email. On the right is the return email address called 'Email Address' unless you have put another email address in 'Reply-to Address'.

2 - Hamburger (top right)/Account Settings/Outgoing Server (SMTP). Highlight the server through which you are sending the email and the User Name is displayed at the bottom. It can be changed using the 'Edit' button.

3 - Hamburger (top right)/Account Settings - click on the 'Server Settings' under the account through which you are sending the email. The email address is in the 'User Name' field.

It's not unusual for an Email provider to change the servers - so doing that with the latest release of their details is worth doing.

As soon as you said 'elderly friend', I felt the hairs on the back of my neck stand up. I look over a couple of elderly people's computers and, amongst other things, the amount of times they click-drag folders and files across their email accounts is frightening - with consequences that have me frequently baffled.

I'm not sure I'll be able to help but there have been a couple of posts recently where people have complained that functionality has been compromised - and it's become apparent a few posts in that the file structure is something worthy of a horror movie plot.

We can manually delete some folders on the HD but it really needs to be seen what the extent of the problem is first.

content:
Is this folder a folder that is stored on my PC rather than somewhere in Thunderbird?

Yes.

Can I move my archived folders (sorted by year) into "Local Folders" and will that improve Thunderbirds performance?

Don't know whether it will improve performance, but it will sure improve the integrity of your mail. Thunderbird stores the contents of each folder in a single mbox file in the filesystem. Keeping your mail stored in huge folders with lots of messages is a bad idea.

You may also want to check this:

https://support.mozilla.org/kb/archived-messages

content:
Thunderbird pri každom spustení kontroluje stav synchronizácie medzi svojim úložiskom správ a poštovým serverom a potom uskutoční všetky potrebné prenosy (stiahne nové správy zo servera, zmaže na serveri všetky správy zmazané v počítači atď.). Kým je Thunderbird spustený a má prístup na Internet, vykonáva nepretržite synchronizáciu s poštovým serverom. Ak internetové pripojenie stratí, spustí synchronizáciu pri obnovení spojenia.

Nesynchronizované správy sú v Thunderbirde stále dostupné. Jediný rozdiel je v tom, že stiahnutá nie je celá správa, ale iba jej „hlavička“. (Hlavička správy obsahuje odosielateľa, príjemcu, predmet, dátum a čas atď. – všetko okrem tela správy.) Telo správy sa nesťahuje, kým nekliknete na správu v zozname správ (čiže pokiaľ nie ste momentálne pripojení na Internet, nemôžete si správu prečítať).

Keď je tých správ obrovské množstvo, tak synchronizácia prebieha aj niekoľko hodín (dní). Časom sa všetky údaje zosynchronizujú. Kliknite na spodnú lištu Thunderbirdu a pozrite si "Správcu činnosti".
creator: Ansamb

content: Synchronizace je dokončená, Thunderbird tvrdí, že je účet aktuální. Přesto tyto e-maily zůstaly s datem první synchronizace, při níž se objevily jako nově doručené, přestože jsou staré (nejstarší je z 2010).
creator: vaclav.mika

content:
Kliknite na priečinok "Doručená pošta" pravým tlačidlom myši a vyberte "Vlastnosti" - kliknite na dlaždicu "Opraviť priečinok"

Kliknite na spodnú lištu Thunderbirdu a pozrite si v "Správcovi činnosti" priebeh opravy.
creator: Ansamb

content: Průběh trval necelou hodinu, výše uvedené e-maily změnily datum a čas na aktuální synchronizaci.
creator: vaclav.mika

content:
He wants me to ask if spectrum has dropped Thunderbird and one of their third party providers

Makes no sense. The email provider doesn't have to support any mail client in particular, it just needs to provide POP and/or IMAP access and give you the configuration settings necessary to use it.

But you do need to know what those settings are supposed to be and set up the account in Thunderbird correctly according to those settings…

content:
This being an IMAP account, you may try removing the account (I'd remove both account info and message data in this case), and set it up in Thunderbird again, indeed. Everything stored on the server should be back when Thunderbird synchronises with the server after setting up the account, but make a backup copy of your profile folder first, just in case.

BUT…

The alert you're getting is weird because you would typically get that alert as a result of having misconfigured Thunderbird to use the wrong mail server, which causes Thunderbird to not be able to find the certificate it expects to find for that kind of server… but you appear to be using the right server for a Gmail account, which means you may encounter the same problem again after re-creating the account in Thunderbird with the same settings…

So you may try re-creating the account in Thunderbird, but I'd like you to post a screenshot of both your incoming and outgoing server settings first, so I may check that everything there is correct.

content:
You only need to backup what the article says, which I'll link here for reference because the link you posted is malformed:

https://support.mozilla.org/kb/profiles-where-thunderbird-stores-user-data

The other profile folder you see under a Local folder is for temporary and cache files, and is kept in a separate directory precisely so you can backup the relevant data without including that.

You may want to backup the whole Thunderbird folder two levels above the profile folder, but definitely not the other part.

EDIT: Post added below to explicitly recommend, not just suggest, backing up the whole enclosing Thunderbird folder.
creator: DavidGG

You can do that deep in the settings of an email account but if you forget to also back up that folder you can lose a lot. PEBKAC of course.

content:
I'm going to somewhat correct myself and definitely recommend backing up not just the profile folder as the KB article says, but the whole Thunderbird folder, so that both the Profiles folder (where profiles are stored by default) AND the accompanying profiles.ini file (which Thunderbird uses to keep track of profiles) are included.

Backing up just the profile folder is enough to ensure the integrity of your Thunderbird data, but backing up the whole Thunderbird folder makes restoring to a different hard drive or moving to a different computer MUCH easier.

If your profile folder is located outside the Thunderbird folder for some reason, then backup that profile folder in addition to the whole Thunderbird folder.

content:
Imap accounts can only display whatever is displayed on the server as seen when you logon to webmail account via a server. This is because all imap folders synchonise with server folders. If you delete emails either via webmail or imap account then they get deleted off server and therefore cannot be displayed in animap account.

A pop account can only access the server Inbox and download mail to the pop account. You can choose to Leave messages on server or have them auto deleted off server when you download. Pop account folders do not synchronise with server. All mail downloaded to a pop account are stored on your computer.

If you have emails in the imap Inbox then they are in server Inbox so when you download to a Pop account Inbox, it should download everything already seen in imap Inbox. You will probably have more folders in the imap account containing emails which are currently on server and cannot be downloaded to the pop account.

You have a choice : Either logon to webmail account and move wanted emails into the Inbox and then download to pop Inbox - however that does mean you need to create folders in the Pop account and then manually move all those downloaded emails into those folders - this can take a long time and is inconvenient. OR and I would advise you do this.... Create folders in 'Local Folders' account to receive copied emails. Then select/highlight emails in imap folder and use Right click > Copy to > select suitably named folder in the 'Local Folders' account. Check they have been copied over correctly. I advise you use 'Copy to' because if something goes wrong you have not lost emails and can try again. I would also advise you do this in batches.

Once you have got good copies of emails you can delete them from the imap folder. Then compact the imap folder when it has been emptied. This will delete emails in that folder off the server. Finally, you can remove the imap account via Account Settings. Select name of account and click on 'Account Actions' and select 'Remove account'.

At this point you can then create necessary folders in the Pop account and perform the same action to get emails into the pop account OR just leave them in Local Folders. Either way, those emails are stored on your computer and therefore it would be a good idea to get a backup.

Backup:

  • Exit Thunderbird
  • Access profile:
  • If Windows OS:
  • In computer search type: %Appdata%
  • Select %Appdata% file folder
  • Select 'Roaming' folder
  • Copy the 'Thunderbird' folder to an external drive.

Start Thunderbird to continue viewing emails.
creator: Toad-Hall

content: Strongly advise: Do not store all your emails in just one folder eg: Inbox because in reality that is just one single text file with emails appended in order they are downloaded. It is somewhat risky to have all your eggs in one basket, if you get my meaning. If that file got corrupted for some reason eg: Anti-Virus tried to fix anything , you may lose emails.

content:
Robert Westinghouse said
My thinking is that I have to copy all this to say: E:\Thunderbird\Profiles\g4lsi6z7.default-esr-1\Mail\webmail.highway1.com.au. Then change the local director using Browse????? Is this right?

As you appear to be a "Local Bloke" I will chime in with my 2¢ and hope I can make it clear enough to make sense. Just be assured the home of BHP is much larger than my very smokey corner of SA

What you proposed there is most certainly not right.

To get Thunderbird to place it's "database" as you term it onto another drive you have to place the entire profile folder structure and contents into the new location with Thunderbird not running.

You then create a new profile using the profile manager in the location you have placed to profile folder and restart Thunderbird. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/profile-manager-create-and-remove-thunderbird-profiles#w_start-the-profile-manager-when-thunderbird-is-closed Or you can use the About:profiles link in the troubleshooting information to create, switch and manage profiles. But that has never been documented, although the same principles apply as for the profile manager. It is also a copy of the same thing in Firefox. For my images I used the About:profiles approach because I can access it without closing Thunderbird.

Once you have gone through the process of pointing to a folder, do not change the profile "name" or the folder selected will change to a new default value.

Here I have set up to create a profile called Whatname in the folder location C:\Users\Matt\AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird\Profiles\69njmd8q.doggy

Once I clicked "finish" on that dialog the newly created profile is added to the list of profiles in about:profiles as shown below.

Now you can launch the profile using the Launch profile in new browser button. It will just open another copy of Thunderbird with that profile (the copy was just a little too exact)

Now here is the bit to watch out for, the new profile will become your default, so everything is good if when you launch it everything looks good. If not you will need to use the "set as default profile" button under your previous default on the C: drive to essentially undo the change of default profile to launch.

Regardless, pressing ⊞Windows key+R to launch the windows run dialog and typing Thunderbird -p in the text area and pressing enter will always launch the profile manager so you can pick another profile is all else fails.

Changing the account directory will see mail for that account stored in the specified location but that is all. I do not see it as a substitute for moving the profile location. You end up creating a rod for your own back at a future time changing the account directory as it makes migrating the profile to a new machine much harder. You have these absolute pointers to your data for the account now that rarely exist in exactly the same form on the new machine as the point you are installing software, so even once you move your profile you will get Thunderbird up and running with your account and contacts and the accounts will be empty.

The is also the issue that calendars, contacts the global search database (mine is many GB is size) and all settings remain on the C: drive in the original location when you only change the account directory.

Now your 2 from the original post.

Thunderbird has no idea what a PST file is, it imports mail from the outlook application via what used to be called dynamic data exchange. That is, Thunderbird asks the Outlook application for say a list of calendars and Outlook offers the requested data. It all works while both applications or on the same page and has no dependence on, what used to be, the constantly changing format of the underlying data storage file (back when this stuff was first written every new release of MS Office came with new file formats and a slew of file import filters). Outlook import has not had much in the way of change since Netscape held the reins other than enough new code to fix it when it actually stops functioning.

So the best approach is to install Thunderbird on a machine with Outlook running as the default mail client and the PST file included as the default in outlook and let the import just do it's thing. It also eliminates the possible issue that the PST is corrupt in some way as outlook will be able to open it if it is not corrupt. Even if the import occurs on the wrong computer, it is far easier to move profiles than it is to try and use third party software you are not familiar with.

content:
Looks like your outgoing (SMTP) server uses a form of authentication known as "POP before SMTP", where the mail client (Thunderbird) has to authenticate with the incoming (POP) server first in order to be able to use the SMTP server. The POP authentication remains valid for a few minutes.

You may be able to solve the problem by checking for new mail more frequently (e.g. every 5 mins, maybe 10), or manually checking for mail right before sending.

content: Well, I don't know your specifics, but generally, when a person changes from one email provider to another, the only way existing messages will get to the new server is if the user manually forwards them. creator: aerotugg1

content:
The most likely scenario is that your account is IMAP, and you did modify the existing account instead of creating a new one for the new server. The new server has no messages yet, hence it did erase all your mail which did previously exist on the old server. This isn't Thunderbird's fault, it's just how IMAP works. You probably should have spent a little more time prior to the switch of the account to determine what needs to be done to preserve your messages.

All that is my best guess, since you provided virtually no details about your setup. Also guessing, you don't have backups of your Thunderbird profile.
